Psychological Bulletin. 1971;75:424&#x2013;429.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">5580548</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Higgins ET. Value from hedonic experience and engagement. Psychological Review. 2006;113:439&#x2013;460.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16802877</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Higgins ET, Scholer AA. Engaging the consumer: The science and art of the value creation process. Journal of Consumer Psychology. 2009;19:100&#x2013;114.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Idson LC, Liberman N, Higgins ET. Distinguishing gains from nonlosses and losses from nongains: A regulatory focus perspective on hedonic intensity. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. 2000;36:252&#x2013;274.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Kimble GA. Hilgard and Marquis' conditioning and learning. Appleton-Century-Crofts; New York: 1961.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wicklund RA. Freedom and reactance. John Wiley &amp; Sons; New York: 1974.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Woodworth RS. Psychology: Fourth Edition. Henry Holt &amp; Company; New York: 1940.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">22711918</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>21</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>48</Volume><Issue>3</Issue><PubDate><Year>2012</Year><Month>May</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Concerns about Appearing Prejudiced Get Under the Skin: Stress Responses to Interracial Contact in the Moment and across Time.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>682</StartPage><EndPage>693</EndPage><MedlinePgn>682-693</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Many White Americans are concerned about appearing prejudiced. How these concerns affect responses during actual interracial interactions, however, remains understudied. The present work examines stress responses to interracial contact-both in the moment, during interracial interactions (Study 1), and over time as individuals have repeated interracial contact (Study 2). Results of Study 1 revealed that concerns about appearing prejudiced were associated with heightened stress responses during interracial encounters (Study 1). White participants concerned about appearing prejudiced exhibited significant increases in cortisol "stress hormone" levels as well as increases in anxious behavior during interracial but not same-race contact. Participants relatively unconcerned about appearing prejudiced did not exhibit these stress responses. Study 2 examined stress responses to interracial contact over an entire academic year. Results revealed that White participants exhibited shifts in cortisol diurnal rhythms on days after interracial contact. Moreover, participants' cortisol rhythms across the academic year, from fall to spring, were related to their concerns about appearing prejudiced and their interracial contact experiences. Taken together, these data offer the first evidence that chronic concerns about appearing prejudiced are related to short- and longer-term stress responses to interracial contact. Implications for life in diverse spaces are discussed.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. 2008;44:1214&#x2013;1217.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC2493421</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">19578470</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Trawalter S, Richeson JA, Shelton JN. Psychological Review. 2006;113(4):862&#x2013;886.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">17014306</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Vorauer JD, Turpie CA. Disruptive effects of vigilance on dominant group members&#x2019; treatment of outgroup members: Choking versus shining under pressure. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2004;87:384&#x2013;399.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15382987</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Word CO, Zanna MP, Cooper J. The nonverbal mediation of self-fulfilling prophecies in interracial interaction. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. 1974;10:109&#x2013;120.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">22639468</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>21</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print-Electronic"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>48</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2012</Year><Month>Mar</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Failure to Consider Future Consequences Increases the Effects of Alcohol on Aggression.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>591</StartPage><EndPage>595</EndPage><MedlinePgn>591-595</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>The failure to consider the future consequences of one's behavior is a major risk factor for aggression. Aggressive people tend to act first, and think later. Some people focus on the -here and now rather than on the future, a tendency measured by the Consideration of Future Consequences (CFC) scale (Strathman, Gleicher, Boninger, &amp; Edwards, 1994). Alcohol intoxication is a neuro-biological variable that produces similar effects. Participants in the present experiment completed the CFC scale and then consumed either an alcohol or a placebo beverage. Next, they competed against a same-sex ostensible partner on an interpersonally adversarial competitive task in which the winner could administer electric shocks to the loser (the aggression measure). As expected, aggression was highest in intoxicated persons with low CFC scores. Being unconcerned about the future consequences of one's actions, in conjunction with acute alcohol intoxication, combine in a pernicious manner to increase aggression.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Bushman</LastName><ForeName>Brad J</ForeName><Initials>BJ</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>The Ohio State University &amp; VU University, Amsterdam, the Netherlands, School of Communication and Department of Psychology.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Giancola</LastName><ForeName>Peter R</ForeName><Initials>PR</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Parrott</LastName><ForeName>Dominic J</ForeName><Initials>DJ</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Roth</LastName><ForeName>Robert M</ForeName><Initials>RM</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 AA011691</GrantID><Acronym>AA</Acronym><Agency>NIAAA NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>R01 AA011691-10</GrantID><Acronym>AA</Acronym><Agency>NIAAA NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList><ArticleDate DateType="Electronic"><Year>2011</Year><Month>12</Month><Day>08</Day></ArticleDate></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2012</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>29</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2012</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>29</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2012</Year><Month>5</Month><Day>29</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">22639468</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS343863</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3357898</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2011.11.013</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Aiken LS, West SG. Biological Psychiatry. 2006;59(4):334&#x2013;340.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16202396</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Steele CM, Josephs RA. Alcohol myopia: Its prized and dangerous effects. American Psychologist. 1990;45:921&#x2013;933.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">2221564</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Strathman A, Gleicher F, Boninger DS, Edwards CS. The consideration of future consequences: Weighing immediate and distant outcomes of behavior. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1994;66(4):742&#x2013;752.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Taylor SP. Aggressive behavior and physiological arousal as a function of provocation and the tendency to inhibit aggression. Journal of Personality. 1967;35:297&#x2013;310.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">6059850</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Whisman MA, McClelland GH. Designing, testing, and interpreting interactions and moderator effects in family research. Journal of Family Psychology. 2005;19:111&#x2013;120.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15796657</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">22389521</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>21</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>48</Volume><Issue>1</Issue><PubDate><Year>2012</Year><Month>Jan</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Strangers in sync: Achieving embodied rapport through shared movements.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>399</StartPage><EndPage>402</EndPage><MedlinePgn>399-402</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>This paper examines the emergence of behavioral synchrony among strangers in the context of self-disclosure, and their path in predicting interaction quality. Specifically, we hypothesize that behavioral synchrony mediates the direct effect of self-disclosure on the development of embodied rapport. Same-sex stranger pairs (n=94) were randomly assigned to a videorecorded self-disclosure or control condition, and afterward each member rated their social interaction. Following the procedure used by Bernieri, Reznick, &amp; Rosenthal (1988), two trained judges independently watched each video record and rated each pair interaction on behavioral synchrony. Bootstrapping analyses provide support for the hypothesized mediating effect of behavioral synchrony, which emerged as independent of the effects of self-other overlap and positive affect. The authors discuss implications of behavioral synchrony for relationship formation processes and the inevitable entwinement of behavior and judgments in light of embodied cognition.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Vacharkulksemsuk</LastName><ForeName>Tanya</ForeName><Initials>T</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, Department of Psychology, Infant affective reactions to the resumption of maternal interaction after the still-face. Child Development. 1996;67:905&#x2013;914.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">8706534</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wiltermuth SS, Heath C. Synchrony and cooperation. Psychological Science. 2009;20:1.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">19152536</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">22368303</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>21</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>48</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2012</Year><Month>Mar</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Who Expressed What Emotion? Men Grab Anger, Women Grab Happiness.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>583</StartPage><EndPage>686</EndPage><MedlinePgn>583-686</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>When anger or happiness flashes on a face in the crowd, do we misperceive that emotion as belonging to someone else? Two studies found that misperception of apparent emotional expressions - "illusory conjunctions" - depended on the gender of the target: male faces tended to "grab" anger from neighboring faces, and female faces tended to grab happiness. Importantly, the evidence did not suggest that this effect was due to the general tendency to misperceive male or female faces as angry or happy, but instead indicated a more subtle interaction of expectations and early visual processes. This suggests a novel aspect of affordance-management in human perception, whereby cues to threat, when they appear, are attributed to those with the greatest capability of doing harm, whereas cues to friendship are attributed to those with the greatest likelihood of providing affiliation opportunities.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Neel</LastName><ForeName>Rebecca</ForeName><Initials>R</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ, 85287. Are effects of emotion expression on trait impressions mediated by babyfaceness? Evidence from connectionist modeling. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 2007;33:648&#x2013;662.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">17440203</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zebrowitz LA, Kikuchi M, Fellous JM. Facial resemblance to emotions: Group differences, impression effects, and race stereotypes. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2010;98:175&#x2013;198.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3677560</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">20085393</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="Publisher" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">26023243</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2019</Year><Month>11</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>48</Volume><Issue>1</Issue><PubDate><Year>2012</Year><Month>Jan</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>The Innuendo Effect: Hearing the Positive but Inferring the Negative.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>77</StartPage><EndPage>85</EndPage><MedlinePgn>77-85</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Speakers can convey mixed impressions by providing only positive information. As a series of studies shows, when communicators omit information on a salient, relevant dimension of social perception, listeners make negative inferences about the target on that omitted dimension, despite directly receiving only positive information on another dimension (Studies 1 and 2a). These negative inferences mediated the effect of the innuendo manipulation on judgments about the target person's suitability for inclusion in one's group. Simulating communication, Study 2b participants read Study 2a's descriptions and showed this innuendo effect is stronger for descriptions of female as opposed to male targets in an academic domain. We discuss implications of innuendo for the communication and perpetuation of mixed impressions and their prevalence in descriptions of subordinate group members.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList On the dominance of moral categories in impression formation. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 1998;24:1251&#x2013;1263.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">22184478</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>21</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>48</Volume><Issue>1</Issue><PubDate><Year>2012</Year><Month>Jan</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>White and Black American Children's Implicit Intergroup Bias.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>264</StartPage><EndPage>270</EndPage><MedlinePgn>264-270</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Despite a decline in explicit prejudice, adults and children from majority groups (e.g., White Americans) often express bias implicitly, as assessed by the Implicit Association Test. In contrast, minority-group (e.g., Black American) adults on average show no bias on the IAT. In the present research, representing the first empirical investigation of whether Black children's IAT responses parallel those of Black adults, we examined implicit bias in 7-11-year-old White and Black American children. Replicating previous findings with adults, whereas White children showed a robust ingroup bias, Black children showed no bias. Additionally, we investigated the role of valuing status in the development of implicit bias. For Black children, explicit preference for high status predicted implicit outgroup bias: Black children who explicitly expressed high preference for rich (vs. poor) people showed an implicit preference for Whites comparable in magnitude to White children's ingroup bias. Implications for research on intergroup bias are discussed.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Newheiser</LastName><ForeName>Anna-Kaisa</ForeName><Initials>AK</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Yale University, New Haven, CT, USA.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Olson</LastName><ForeName>Kristina R</ForeName><Initials>KR</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R03 HD059996</GrantID><Acronym>HD</Acronym><Agency>NICHD NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>R03 HD059996-02</GrantID><Acronym>HD</Acronym><Agency>NICHD NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2011</Year><Month>12</Month><Day>21</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2011</Year><Month>12</Month><Day>21</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2011</Year><Month>12</Month><Day>21</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">22184478</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS321254</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3241011</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2011.08.011</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Aboud F. Journal of Youth and Adolescence. 2005;34:437&#x2013;445.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21874067</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Sep</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>I only have eyes for you: Ovulation redirects attention (but not memory) to attractive men.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>804</StartPage><EndPage>808</EndPage><MedlinePgn>804-808</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>A number of studies have found a disjunction between women's attention to, and memory for, handsome men. Although women pay initial attention to handsome men, they do not remember those men later. The present study examines how ovulation might differentially affect these attentional and memory processes. We found that women near ovulation increased their visual attention to attractive men. However, this increased visual attention did not translate into better memory. Discussion focuses on possible explanations, in the context of an emerging body of findings on disjunctions between attention to, and memory for, other people.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Anderson</LastName><ForeName>Uriah S</ForeName><Initials>US</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology, Arizona State University, P.O. Women&#x2019;s oestradiol predicts preference for facial cues of men&#x2019;s testosterone. Hormones and Behavior. 2008;53:14&#x2013;19.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">17950291</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wiederman MW, Hurd C. Extradyadic involvement during dating. Journal of Social and Personal Relationships. 1999;16:265&#x2013;274.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21836728</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>47</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2011</Year><Month>Mar</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>The effects of time perspective and level of construal on social distance.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>397</StartPage><EndPage>402</EndPage><MedlinePgn>397-402</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Psychological causes of social distance were examined from the perspective of Construal Level Theory (CLT; Liberman, Trope, &amp; Stephan, 2007), which predicts that temporal distance from and abstract construal of a social target would create perception of social distance. Our studies demonstrate that expectations for temporally remote (versus proximal) social interaction produce greater social distance from a target person, measured as reduced familiarity (Study 1) and as reduced similarity to the self (Study 2). We also show that a more abstract, higher level construal of a social target results in less familiarity (Study 3) and in less allocation of resources (Study 4). The research sheds light on how social closeness can be promoted or hindered by previously unaddressed psychological factors.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author European Journal of Social Psychology. 1999;29:95&#x2013;104.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wilder DA. Social categorization: Implications for creation and reduction of intergroup bias. Attitudinal effects of mere exposure. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology Monograph Supplement. 1968;9(2):1&#x2013;27.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21804647</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Sep</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Intergroup Contact Facilitates Physiological Recovery following Stressful Intergroup Interactions.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>854</StartPage><EndPage>858</EndPage><MedlinePgn>854-858</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>A growing body of research has demonstrated the importance of intergroup contact in reducing fear, threat and anxiety in intergroup domains. Here we focus on the regulatory benefits of intergroup contact. We hypothesized that past intergroup contact would facilitate recovery from a stressful intergroup evaluation. White and Black participants completed a stressful evaluative task in the presence of two White or two Black interviewers while autonomic nervous system and hormonal responses were assessed. When examining how participants recovered after the stressful task, intergroup contact predicted faster physiological recovery for both autonomic and neuroendocrine reactivity. The importance of recovery from stress for physiological resilience in diverse contexts is discussed.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Page-Gould</LastName><ForeName>Elizabeth</ForeName><Initials>E</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology, University of Toronto Scarborough.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Mendes</LastName><ForeName>Wendy Berry</ForeName><Initials>WB</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Major</LastName><ForeName>Brenda</ForeName><Initials>B</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 HL079383</GrantID><Acronym>HL</Acronym><Agency>NHLBI NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>R01 HL079383-05</GrantID><Acronym>HL</Acronym><Agency>NHLBI NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2011</Year><Month>8</Month><Day>2</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2011</Year><Month>8</Month><Day>2</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2011</Year><Month>8</Month><Day>2</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">21804647</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS207835</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3144855</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2010.04.006</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Allport GW. Psychosomatic Medicine. 2001;63:650&#x2013;657.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">11485119</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Olsson A, Ebert JP, Banaji MR, Phelps EA. Boston, MA, US: Beacon Press; (In Press)</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Page-Gould E, Mendoza-Denton R, Tropp LR. With a little help from my cross-group friend: Reducing anxiety in intergroup contexts through cross-group friendship. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2008;95:1080&#x2013;1094.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18954195</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Paolini S, Hewstone M, Cairns E, Voci A. Effects of direct and indirect cross-group friendships on judgments of Catholics and Protestants in Northern Ireland: The mediating role of an anxiety-reduction mechanism. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 2004;30:770&#x2013;786.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15155040</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Pettigrew TF. Intergroup contact theory. Annual review of psychology. 1998;49:65&#x2013;85.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15012467</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Stephan WG, Stephan CW. Intergroup anxiety. Journal of Social Issues. 1985;41:157&#x2013;175.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Stephan WG, Stephan CW. An integrated threat theory of prejudice. In: Oskamp S, editor. Reducing prejudice and discrimination. The Claremont Symposium on Applied Social Psychology. Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates; 2000. pp. 23&#x2013;45.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Stranahan AM, Lee K, Mattson MP. Central mechanisms of HPA axis regulation by voluntary exercise. NeuroMolecular Medicine. 2008;10:118&#x2013;127.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3010733</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18273712</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Trawalter S, Richeson JA, Shelton JN. Predicting behavior during interracial interactions: A stress and coping approach. Personality and Social Psychology Review. 2009;13:243&#x2013;268.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">19778939</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21789027</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>47</Volume><Issue>4</Issue><PubDate><Year>2011</Year><Month>Jul</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>What You Feel Influences What You See: The Role of Affective Feelings in Resolving Binocular Rivalry.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>856</StartPage><EndPage>860</EndPage><MedlinePgn>856-860</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>It seems obvious that what you see influences what you feel, but what if the opposite were also true? What if how you feel can shape your visual experience? In this experiment, we demonstrate that the affective state of a perceiver influences the contents of visual awareness. Participants received positive, negative, and neutral affect inductions and then completed a series of binocular rivalry trials in which a face (smiling, scowling or neutral) was presented to one eye and a house to the other. The percepts "competed" for dominance in visual consciousness. We found, as predicted, that all faces (smiling, scowling, and neutral) were dominant for longer when perceivers experienced unpleasant affect compared to when they were in a neutral state (a social vigilance effect), although scowling faces increased their dominance when perceivers felt unpleasant (a relative negative congruence effect). Relatively speaking, smiling faces increased their dominance more when perceivers were experiencing pleasant affect (a positive congruence effect). These findings illustrate that the affective state of a perceiver serves as a context that influences the contents of consciousness.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Anderson</LastName><ForeName>Eric</ForeName><Initials>E</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Northeastern University.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Siegel</LastName><ForeName>Erika H</ForeName><Initials>EH</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Barrett</LastName><ForeName>Lisa Subcortical connections of inferior temporal areas TE and TEO in macaque monkeys. Journal of Comparative Neurology. 1993;335:73&#x2013;91.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">8408774</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Whittle P. Binocular rivalry and the contrast at contours. Journal of Experimental Psychology. 1965;17:217&#x2013;226.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">5825693</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zikopoulos B, Barbas H. Parallel driving and modulatory pathways link the prefrontal cortex and thalamus. PLoS One. 2007;9:1&#x2013;19.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC1952177</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">17786219</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21779130</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>47</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2011</Year><Month>Sep</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>The Impact of Power on Information Processing Depends on Cultural Orientation.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>959</StartPage><EndPage>967</EndPage><MedlinePgn>959-967</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Two studies show that different culturally based concepts of interpersonal power have distinct implications for information processing. People with a vertical individualist (VI) cultural orientation view power in personalized terms (power is for gaining status over and recognition by others), whereas people with a horizontal collectivist (HC) cultural orientation view power in socialized terms (power is for benefitting and helping others). The distinct goals associated with these power concepts are served by different mindsets, such as stereotyping others versus learning the individuating needs of others. Therefore, for high-VI individuals, making personalized power salient increases stereotyping in processing product information. That is, they recognize better information that is congruent with their prior product expectations, relative to their recognition of incongruent information. In contrast, for high-HC people, making socialized power salient increases individuating processes, characterized by better memory for incongruent information.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList The Power Motive. New York, NY, US: Free Press; 1973.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wyer RS, Budesheim TL, Shavitt S, Riggle ED, Melton R, Kuklinski JH. Image, issues, and ideology: The processing of information about political candidates. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1991;61(4):533&#x2013;545.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">1960646</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21765541</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>47</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2011</Year><Month>Sep</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>What Remains on Your Mind After You Are Done?: Flexible Regulation of Knowledge Accessibility.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>882</StartPage><EndPage>890</EndPage><MedlinePgn>882-890</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>The accessibility of stored knowledge has been found to decline over time after activation without further stimulation. A special case is goal pursuit; goal-related knowledge remains accessible until goal completion, and then its accessibility declines rapidly. We hypothesized that after goal completion the decline in accessibility of goal-related knowledge would be especially rapid for strong promotion-focused individuals because their motivation to eagerly advance beyond the status quo would make accessibility of this knowledge an irrelevant detriment. We hypothesized an opposite effect for strongly prevention-predominant individuals because their motivation to vigilantly maintain a satisfactory state would make accessibility of this knowledge continually relevant. The results of two studies supported both these predicted moderators of accessibility change. Indeed, we found that for strongly prevention-predominant participants, knowledge accessibility actually increased over time after goal completion. We discuss how even basic cognitive mechanisms, like changes in accessibility, can be affected by general motivational concerns.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Hedberg</LastName><ForeName>Per H</ForeName><Initials>PH</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology, Columbia University; Stockholm School of Economics, Sweden.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Higgins</LastName><ForeName>E Tory</ForeName><Initials>ET</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH039429</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH039429-20</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2011</Year><Month>7</Month><Day>19</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2011</Year><Month>7</Month><Day>19</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2011</Year><Month>7</Month><Day>19</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">21765541</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS283264</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3134315</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2011.03.008</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Aiken LS, West SG. How semantic is automatic semantic priming? Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition. 1992;18:1191&#x2013;1210.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">1447547</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Shoben EJ. The psychology of learning. Teachers College; New York: 1914.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Tulving E, Pearlstone Z. Availability versus accessibility of information in memory for words. Journal of Verbal Learning and Verbal Behavior. 1966;5:381&#x2013;391.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wegner D. White Bears and Other Unwanted Thoughts. Guilford; New York: 1989.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wegner DM. Ironic processes of mental control. Psychological Review. 1994;101:34&#x2013;52.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">8121959</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zeigarnik B. Das Behalten erledigter und unerledigter Handlungen [The retention of completed and uncompleted actions] Psychologische Forschung. 1927;9:1&#x2013;85.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21691437</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>47</Volume><Issue>4</Issue><PubDate><Year>2011</Year><Month>Jul</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Contextual Variation in Automatic Evaluative Bias to Racially-Ambiguous Faces.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>818</StartPage><EndPage>823</EndPage><MedlinePgn>818-823</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Three studies examined the implicit evaluative associations activated by racially-ambiguous Black-White faces. In the context of both Black and White faces, Study 1 revealed a graded pattern of bias against racially-ambiguous faces that was weaker than the bias to Black faces but stronger than that to White faces. Study 2 showed that significant bias was present when racially-ambiguous faces appeared in the context of only White faces, but not in the context of only Black faces. Study 3 demonstrated that context produces perceptual contrast effects on racial-prototypicality judgments. Racially-ambiguous faces were perceived as more prototypically Black in a White-only than mixed-race context, and less prototypically Black in a Black-only context. Conversely, they were seen as more prototypically White in a Black-only than mixed context, and less prototypically White in a White-only context. The studies suggest that both race-related featural properties within a face (i.e., racial ambiguity) and external contextual factors affect automatic evaluative associations.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Ito</LastName><ForeName>Tiffany Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2009;96:795&#x2013;810.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3750059</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">19309203</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Peery D, Bodenhausen GV. Psychological Science. 2008;19:973&#x2013;977.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">19000204</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Rhodes G, Lie HC, Ewing LA, Evangelista E, Tanaka JW. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory &amp; Cognition. 2010;36:217&#x2013;223.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">20053057</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Webster MA, Kaping D, Mizokami Y, Duhamel P. Adaptation to natural facial categories. Nature. 2004;428:561.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15058304</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Willadsen-Jensen EC, Ito TA. Ambiguity and the timecourse of racial categorization. Social Cognition. 2006;24:580&#x2013;606.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Willadsen-Jensen EC, Ito TA. The Effect of Context on Responses to Racially-ambiguous Faces: Changes in Perception and Evaluation. 2010 Manuscript under review.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC4483557</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">25344946</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wittenbrink B, Judd CM, Park B. Spontaneous prejudice in context: Variability in automatically activated attitudes. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2001;81:815&#x2013;827.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">11708559</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21643510</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>47</Volume><Issue>4</Issue><PubDate><Year>2011</Year><Month>Jul</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Eyes on the prize: The longitudinal benefits of goal focus on progress toward a weight loss goal.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>853</StartPage><EndPage>855</EndPage><MedlinePgn>853-855</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Past research suggests that focusing on what has not yet been accomplished (goal focus) signals a lack of progress towards one's high commitment goals and inspires greater motivation than does focusing on what has already been accomplished (accomplishment focus). The present investigation extends this research to a longitudinal, important domain by exploring the consequences of focusing on one's goals versus accomplishments when pursuing a weight loss goal. Participants were tracked over the course of a 12-week weight loss program that utilized weekly group discussions and a companion website to direct participants' focus toward their end weight loss goal or toward what they had already achieved. Goal-focused participants reported higher levels of commitment to their goal and, ultimately, lost more weight than did accomplishment-focused and no focus control participants. Accomplishment-focused participants did not differ from controls on any measure.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Conlon</LastName><ForeName>Kyle E</ForeName><Initials>KE</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology, Florida State University.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Ehrlinger</LastName><ForeName>Joyce</ForeName><Initials>J</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Eibach</LastName><ForeName>Richard Obesity Research. 2003;11:888&#x2013;894.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">12855759</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Kassirer JP, Angell MA. Losing weight: An ill-fated new year&#x2019;s resolution. New England Journal of Medicine. 1998;338:52&#x2013;54.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">9414332</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Koo M, Fishbach A. Dynamics of self-regulation: How (un)accomplished goal actions affect motivation. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2008;94:183&#x2013;195.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18211171</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Shah M, Simha V, Garg A. Long-term impact of bariatric surgery on body weight, comorbidities, and nutritional status. Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism. 2006;91:4223&#x2013;4231.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16954156</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Singer JD, Willett JB. Applied longitudinal data analysis: Modeling change and event occurrence. New York, NY: Oxford University Press; 2003.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wadden TA, Foster GD, Letizia KA, Stunkard AJ. A multicenter evaluation of a proprietary weight reduction program for the treatment of marked obesity. Archives of Internal Medicine. 1992;152:961&#x2013;966.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">1580722</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">23606756</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>21</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>47</Volume><Issue>3</Issue><PubDate><Year>2011</Year><Month>May</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Vicarious goal satiation.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>685</StartPage><EndPage>688</EndPage><MedlinePgn>685-688</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>A signature feature of self-regulation is that once a goal is satiated, it becomes deactivated, thereby allowing people to engage in new pursuits. The present experiments provide evidence for <i>vicarious goal satiation</i>, a novel phenomenon in which individuals experience "post-completion goal satiation" as a result of unwittingly taking on another person's goal pursuit and witnessing its completion. In Experiments 1 and 2, the observation of a goal being completed (vs. not completed) led to less striving by the observer on the same task. Given that an actor's strength of commitment affects goal contagion, we hypothesized that such commitment would be an important boundary condition for vicarious goal satiation. The results of Experiment 2 showed that observing stronger (vs. weaker) goal commitment lowered accessibility of goal-related words, but only when the goal being observed was completed. Implications of vicarious goal satiation for goal pursuit in everyday environments are discussed.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Automatic for the people: How representations of significant others implicitly affect goal pursuit. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2003;84:661&#x2013;681.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">12703642</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wesselmann ED, Bagg D, Williams KD. &#x201c;I feel your pain&#x201d;: The effects of observing ostracism on the ostracism detection system. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. 2009;45:1308&#x2013;1311.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21516174</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>47</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2011</Year><Month>Mar</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Smooth Trajectories Travel Farther into the Future: Perceptual Fluency Effects on Prediction of Trend Continuation.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>506</StartPage><EndPage>508</EndPage><MedlinePgn>506-508</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>This research examines how processing fluency influences people's perceptions of whether a trend will continue into the future. Specifically, three studies hypothesized that people who read descriptions of increasing or decreasing trends in easy-to-read font would be more likely to predict that the trend would continue into the future, compared to people exposed to difficult-to-read font. Studies 1 and 2 establish this effect for an increasing trend, whereas Study 3 replicates the findings with a decreasing trend. Taken together, these results suggest processing fluency as a factor that affects assessment of future potential.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Huang</LastName><ForeName>Julie Y</ForeName><Initials>JY</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Yale University.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Song</LastName><ForeName>Hyunjin</ForeName><Initials>H</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Bargh</LastName><ForeName>John A</ForeName><Initials>JA</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH060767</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH060767-10</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2011</Year><Month>4</Month><Day>26</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2011</Year><Month>4</Month><Day>26</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2011</Year><Month>4</Month><Day>26</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">21516174</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS258619</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3079957</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2010.12.002</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Alter AL, Oppenheimer DM. If it's hard to read, it's hard to do: Processing fluency affects effort prediction and motivation. Psychological Science. 2008b;19:986&#x2013;988.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">19000208</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Song H, Schwarz N. If it's difficult to pronounce, it must be risky: Fluency, familiarity, and risk perception. Psychological Science. 2009;20:135&#x2013;138.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">19170941</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Whittlesea BWA, Jacoby LL, Girard K. Illusions of immediate memory: Evidence of an attributional basis for feelings of familiarity and perceptual quality. Journal of Memory and Language. 1990;29:716&#x2013;732.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21499547</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>47</Volume><Issue>1</Issue><PubDate><Year>2011</Year><Month>Jan</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>The Color of Safety: Ingroup Associated Colors make Beer Safer.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>190</StartPage><EndPage>194</EndPage><MedlinePgn>190-194</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Individuals display high levels of trust and express feelings of safety when interacting with social ingroup members. Here, we investigated whether cues related to ingroup membership would change perceptions of the safety of alcohol. Participants were exposed to images of beer in either a standard can or a can featuring the colors of their university (i.e., 'fan cans'). We hypothesized that exposure to fan cans would change perceptions of the risks of beer drinking. Results showed that participants exposed to fan cans rated beer consumption as less dangerous (Experiment 1), were more likely to automatically activate safety-related mental content after unconscious perception of beer cues (Experiment 2), and viewed their ingroup's party practices as less dangerous (Experiment 3). These results provide evidence that ingroup-associated colors can serve as a safety cue for alcohol, which may in theory perpetuate alcohol-related risk-taking, already a cause for concern on college and university campuses.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author The link between identification and in-group favouritism: Effects of threat to social identity and trust-related emotions. British Journal of Social Psychology. 2006;45:265&#x2013;284.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16762101</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Weinbach J. Inside college sports&#x2019; biggest money machine: What do you get for $109 million a year? Jon Weinbach on Ohio State&#x2019;s record-breaking budget. The Wall Street Journal Online. 2007. Oct 19,  Retrieved from  http://online.wsj.com.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21344058</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>47</Volume><Issue>1</Issue><PubDate><Year>2011</Year><Month>Jan</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Dangerous Enough: Moderating Racial Bias with Contextual Threat Cues.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>184</StartPage><EndPage>189</EndPage><MedlinePgn>184-189</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Research shows that participants shoot armed Blacks more frequently and quickly than armed Whites, but make don't-shoot responses more frequently and quickly for unarmed Whites than unarmed Blacks. We argue that this bias reflects the perception of threat - specifically, threat associated with Black males. Other danger cues (not just race) may create a similar predisposition to shoot, and if these cues promote shooting when the target is White, they should attenuate racial bias. We embedded targets in threatening andsafe backgrounds. Racial bias was evident in safe contexts but disappeared when context signaled danger, and this reduction was largely due to an increased tendency to shoot White targets.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Correll</LastName><ForeName>Joshua</ForeName><Initials>J</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>University The Police: Six Sociological Essays. New York: Wiley; 1967.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wittenbrink B, Park B, Judd CM. Spontaneous prejudice in context: Variability in automatically activated attitudes. Journal of Personality &amp; Social Psychology. 2001;81:815&#x2013;827.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">11708559</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21057662</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>6</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Nov</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Attachment Insecurity and Perceived Partner Suffering as Predictors of Personal Distress.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>1143</StartPage><EndPage>1147</EndPage><MedlinePgn>1143-1147</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>This study examined the extent to which perceptions of partner suffering mediate the association between attachment insecurity (anxiety and avoidance) and personal distress among spouses of older adults with osteoarthritis. Fifty-three spouses watched two videos of targets (their partner and an opposite sex stranger) perform a pain-eliciting household task, and spouses were asked to rate their own distress and perceptions of the targets' pain. Spouses also completed self-report measures of trait attachment. Results revealed that attachment anxiety was associated with greater personal distress in reaction to the partner's suffering, and heightened perceptions of partner pain mediated this association. Avoidant attachment was associated with less distress in reaction to the partner's suffering, but not with less perceived pain. The results of this study identify an important mechanism linking attachment insecurity and heightened distress responses when observing the suffering of a significant other.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Monin</LastName><ForeName>Joan K</ForeName><Initials>JK</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>University Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2001;81(6):1205&#x2013;1224.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">11761318</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Muller D, Judd CM, Yzerbt VY. When moderation is mediated and mediation is moderated. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2005;89(6):852&#x2013;863.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16393020</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Romano JM, Turner JA, Friedman LS, Bulcroft RA, Jensen MP, Hops H. Observational assessment of chronic pain patient-spouse behavioral interaction. Behavior Therapy. 1991;22:549&#x2013;568.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20824201</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Sep</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Incentivizing education: Seeing schoolwork as an investment, not a chore.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>846</StartPage><EndPage>849</EndPage><MedlinePgn>846-849</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Most American children expect to attend college but because they do not necessarily spend much time on schoolwork, they may fail to reach their imagined "college-bound" future self. The proposed identity-based motivation model helps explain why this gap occurs: Imagined "college-bound" identities cue school-focused behavior if they are salient and feel relevant to current choice options, not otherwise. Two studies with predominantly low-income and African American middle school students support this prediction. Almost all of the students expect to attend college, but only half describe education-dependent (e.g., law, medicine) adult identities. Having education-dependent rather than education-independent adult identities (e.g., sports, entertainment) predicts better grades over time, controlling for prior grade point average (Study 1). To demonstrate causality, salience of education-dependent versus education-independent adult identities was experimentally manipulated. Children who considered education-dependent adult identities (vs. education-independent ones) were eight times more likely to complete a take-home extra credit assignment (Study 2).</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Destin</LastName><ForeName>Mesmin</ForeName><Initials>M</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>University of Michigan.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Oyserman</LastName><ForeName>Daphna</ForeName><Initials>D</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH058299-01A2</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>T32 MH063057</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2010</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>9</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2010</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>9</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2010</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>9</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">20824201</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS199565</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC2930839</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2010.04.004</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Adelman RM, Gocker JC. Retrieved April 2006, from  www.census.gov.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>U.S. Census Bureau. Current population survey, annual social and economic supplement. 2006.  Retrieved January 2008, from  www.census.gov.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>U.S. Census Bureau. 2008 Current Income Data. Mar, 2009.  from  http://www.census.gov/hhes/www/income/income.html.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20652087</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>4</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Jul</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Shedding light on insight: Priming bright ideas.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>696</StartPage><EndPage>700</EndPage><MedlinePgn>696-700</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Previous research has characterized insight as the product of internal processes, and has thus investigated the cognitive and motivational processes that immediately precede it. In this research, however, we investigate whether insight can be catalyzed by a cultural artifact, an external object imbued with learned meaning. Specifically, we exposed participants to an illuminating lightbulb - an iconic image of insight - prior to or during insight problem-solving. Across four studies, exposing participants to an illuminating lightbulb primed concepts associated with achieving an insight, and enhanced insight problem-solving in three different domains (spatial, verbal, and mathematical), but did not enhance general (non-insight) problem-solving.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Thoughts beyond words: When language overshadows insight. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General. 1993;122:166&#x2013;183.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Siegler RS. Unconscious insights. Current Directions in Psychological Science. 2000;9:79&#x2013;83.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Soldz S, Vaillant GE. The big five personality traits and the life course: A 45 year longitudinal study. Journal of Research in Personality. 1999;33:208&#x2013;232.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Taylor CW. Various approaches to and definitions of creativity. In: Sternberg RJ, editor. The nature of creativity. Cambridge University Press; New York: 1988. pp. 99&#x2013;121.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wallas G. The art of thought. Franklin Watts; New York: 1926.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20526451</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>4</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Jul</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>The Big, the Bad, and the Boozed-Up: Weight Moderates the Effect of Alcohol on Aggression.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>619</StartPage><EndPage>623</EndPage><MedlinePgn>619-623</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Most people avoid the "big, drunk guy" in bars because they don't want to get assaulted. Is this stereotype supported by empirical evidence? Unfortunately, no scientific work has investigated this topic. Based on the recalibrational theory of anger and embodied cognition theory, we predicted that heavier men would behave the most aggressively when intoxicated. In two independent experiments (Ns= 553 and 327, respectively), participants consumed either alcohol or placebo beverages and then completed an aggression task in which they could administer painful electric shocks to a fictitious opponent. Both experiments showed that weight interacted with alcohol and gender to predict the highest amount of aggression among intoxicated heavy men. The results suggest that an embodied cognition approach is useful in understanding intoxicated aggression. Apparently there is a kernel of truth in the stereotype of the "big, drunk, aggressive guy."</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Aggressive behavior and physiological arousal as a function of provocation and the tendency to inhibit aggression. Journal of Personality. 1967;35:297&#x2013;310.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">6059850</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>West SG, Brown TJ. Physical attractiveness, the severity of the emergency and helping: A field experiment and interpersonal simulation. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. 1975;11:531&#x2013;538.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20526450</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>4</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Jul</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>A Smart Unconscious? Procedural Origins of Automatic Partner Attitudes in Marriage.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>650</StartPage><EndPage>656</EndPage><MedlinePgn>650-656</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>The paper examines potential origins of automatic (i.e., unconscious) attitudes toward one's marital partner. It tests the hypothesis that early experiences in conflict-of-interest situations predict one's later automatic inclination to approach (or avoid) the partner. A longitudinal study linked daily experiences in conflict-of-interest situations in the initial months of new marriages to automatic evaluations of the partner assessed four years later using the Implicit Associations Test. The results revealed that partners who were initially (1) treated less responsively and (2) evidenced more self-protective and less connectedness-promoting "if-then" contingencies in their thoughts and behavior later evidenced less positive automatic partner attitudes. However, these factors did not predict changes in love, satisfaction, or explicit beliefs about the partner. The findings hint at the existence of a "smart" relationship unconscious that captures behavioral realities conscious reflection can miss.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Psychological Review. 2007;14:843&#x2013;863.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">17907866</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zayas V, Shoda Y. Do automatic reactions elicited by thoughts of romantic partner, mother, and self relate to adult romantic attachment? Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 2005;8:1011&#x2013;1025.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16000264</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20495619</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>3</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>May</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>I Like the Sound of Your Voice: Affective Learning about Vocal Signals.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>557</StartPage><EndPage>563</EndPage><MedlinePgn>557-563</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>This paper provides the first demonstration that the content of what a talker says is sufficient to imbue the acoustics of his voice with affective meaning. In two studies, participants listened to male talkers utter positive, negative, or neutral words. Next, participants completed a sequential evaluative priming task where a neutral word spoken by one of the same talkers was presented before each target word to be evaluated. We predicted, and found, that voices served as evaluative primes that influenced the speed with which participants evaluated the target words. These two experiments demonstrate that the human voice can take on affective meaning merely based on the positive or negative value of the words uttered by that voice. Implications for affective processing, the pragmatics of communication, and person-perception are discussed.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Conventional, biological, and environmental factors in speech communication: A modulation theory. Phonetica. 1994;51:170&#x2013;183.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">8052672</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Yamada N, Hakoda Y, Yuda E, Kusuhara A. Verification of impression voice in relation to occupational categories. Psychological Reports. 2000;86:1249&#x2013;1263.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">10932591</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zuckerman M, Miyake K. The attractive voice: what makes it so? Journal of Nonverbal Behavior. 1993;17:119&#x2013;135.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20401323</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2022</Year><Month>03</Month><Day>16</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Mar</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Building Self-Control Strength: Practicing Self-Control Leads to Improved Self-Control Performance.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>465</StartPage><EndPage>468</EndPage><MedlinePgn>465-468</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Self-control performance may be improved by the regular practice of small acts of self-control. Ninety-two adults' self-control capacity was assessed using the stop signal paradigm before they started practicing self-control and again at the end of two weeks. Participants who practiced self-control by cutting back on sweets or squeezing a handgrip exhibited significant improvement in stop signal performance relative to those who practiced tasks that did not require self-control. Participants who did not practice self-control believed that the tasks should improved self-control, engaged in tasks that were effortful and made self-control salient, but did not actually require self-control. Supplemental analyses suggested that only practicing self-control built self-control capacity; the improved outcomes cannot be explained by self-fulfilling prophecies, increased self-efficacy or awareness of self-control. The results may have implications for understanding the development of self-control in both children and adults, as well as clinical implications for treating disorders that involve low self-control.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Muraven</LastName><ForeName>Mark</ForeName><Initials>M</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology, University at Albany, Albany, NY 12222.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 DA016131</GrantID><Acronym>DA</Acronym><Agency>NIDA NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>R01 DA016131-01A1</GrantID><Acronym>DA</Acronym><Agency>NIDA NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2010</Year><Month>4</Month><Day>20</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2010</Year><Month>4</Month><Day>20</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2010</Year><Month>4</Month><Day>20</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">20401323</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS170290</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC2855143</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2009.12.011</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Baumeister RF, Bratslavsky E, Muraven M, Tice DM.
