British Journal of Health Psychology. 2006b;11:717&#x2013;733.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">17032494</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Perrine MW, Mundt JC, Searles JS, Lester LS. Validation of daily self-reported alcohol consumption using interactive voice response (ivr) technology. Journal of Studies on Alcohol. 1995;56:487&#x2013;490.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">7475027</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Rethlingshafer D. Relationship of tests of persistence to other measures of continuance of activities. Journal of Abnormal Social Psychology. 1942;37:71&#x2013;82.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Searles JS, Perrine MW, Mundt JC, Helzer JE. Self-report of drinking using touch-tone telephone: Extending the limits of reliable daily contact. Journal of Studies on Alcohol. 1995;56:375&#x2013;382.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">7674671</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Thornton GR. A factor analysis of tests designed to measure persistence. Psychological Monographs. 1939;51:1&#x2013;42.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20401175</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Mar</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Threatened Selves and Differential Prejudice Expression by White and Black Perceivers.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>469</StartPage><EndPage>473</EndPage><MedlinePgn>469-473</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Previous theorizing suggests that often-stigmatized individuals may be just as likely, if not more likely, than infrequently stigmatized individuals to protect self-regard by derogating members of low-status groups after receiving negative feedback from high-status others. Often-stigmatized individuals, however, can discount criticism from these high-status others as reflecting prejudice, thereby making outgroup derogation unnecessary as an esteem-protective strategy. Replicating past research, White participants in Experiment 1 expressed prejudices after receiving negative feedback from a White evaluator; as predicted, however, Black participants did not. In Experiment 2, participants instead received negative feedback from Black evaluators (evaluators more likely to threaten Black participants' self-regard). Here, contrary to previous theorizing, Black participants expressed prejudices, not toward another low-status group, but toward high-status Whites. In all, findings reveal flaws in previous assumptions that frequently stigmatized individuals may be especially prone to devalue lower-status others after rejection or negative feedback from members of higher-status groups.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Shapiro</LastName><ForeName>Jenessa Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2008;95:877&#x2013;898.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18808265</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Shelton JN. A reconceptualization of how we study issues of racial prejudice. Personality and Social Psychology Review. 2000;4:374&#x2013;390.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Shelton JN, Richeson JA. New York, NY: Academic Press; 2006. pp. 121&#x2013;181.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Spencer SJ, Fein S, Wolfe CT, Fong C, Dunn MA. Automatic activation of stereotypes: The role of self-image threat. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 1998;24:1139&#x2013;1152.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20401162</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Mar</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Malleability of Attitudes or Malleability of the IAT?</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>286</StartPage><EndPage>298</EndPage><MedlinePgn>286-298</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>In the current set of experiments, we establish, and explore the consequences of, the imprecision that characterizes the attribute response labels typically employed in the Implicit Association Test (IAT). In Experiment 1, we demonstrate the malleability of the IAT, as conventionally implemented. IAT scores are shown to be influenced by perspective mindsets induced by an unrelated preceding task. Then, we explore how the malleability of the IAT can lead to the inference that attitude change has occurred even when there is very good reason to believe it has not (Experiment 2), and conversely, how it can obscure the detection of attitude change when such change is indeed likely to have occurred (Experiment 3). We provide conceptual explanations for these discrepancies and suggest methodological improvements to enhance the specificity of IAT measures.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList Spontaneous prejudice in context: Variability in automatically activated attitudes. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2001;81:815&#x2013;827.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">11708559</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Yoshida E, Peach JM, Spencer SJ, Zanna MP. Automatic evaluation of what most people like: Developing an implicit measure of norms; Paper presented at the 7th Annual meeting of the Society for Personality and Social Psychology; Palm Springs, CA. 2006.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20368752</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Mar</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Mating Competitors Increase Religious Beliefs.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>428</StartPage><EndPage>431</EndPage><MedlinePgn>428-431</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>It has been presumed that religiosity has an influence on mating behavior, but here we experimentally investigate the possibility that mating behavior might also influence religiosity. In Experiment 1, people reported higher religiosity after looking at mating pools consisting of attractive people of their own sex compared to attractive opposite sex targets. Experiment 2 replicated the effect with an added control group, and suggested that both men and women become more religious when seeing same sex competitors. We discuss several possible explanations for these effects. Most broadly, the findings contribute to an emerging literature on how cultural phenomena such as religiosity respond to ecological cues in potentially functional ways.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Li</LastName><ForeName>Yexin Jessica</ForeName><Initials>YJ</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department Chicago, IL: Aldine; 1972. pp. 136&#x2013;179.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Weeden J, Cohen AB, Kenrick DT. Religious participation and reproductive strategies. Evolution and Human Behavior. 2008;29:327&#x2013;334.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3161130</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">21874105</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="Publisher" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20228874</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2022</Year><Month>03</Month><Day>30</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Mar</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Aversive Racism and Medical Interactions with Black Patients: A Field Study.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>436</StartPage><EndPage>440</EndPage><MedlinePgn>436-440</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Medical interactions between Black patients and nonBlack physicians are usually less positive and productive than same-race interactions. We investigated the role that physician explicit and implicit biases play in shaping physician and patient reactions in racially discordant medical interactions. We hypothesized that whereas physicians' explicit bias would predict their own reactions, physicians' implicit bias, in combination with physician explicit (self-reported) bias, would predict patients' reactions. Specifically, we predicted that patients would react most negatively when their physician fit the profile of an aversive racist (i.e., low explicit-high implicit bias). The hypothesis about the effects of explicit bias on physicians' reactions was partially supported. The aversive racism hypothesis received support. Black patients had less positive reactions to medical interactions with physicians relatively low in explicit but relatively high in implicit bias than to interactions with physicians who were either (a) low in both explicit and implicit bias, or (b) high in both explicit and implicit bias.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Patient Education and Counseling. 2006;62:355&#x2013;360.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16860520</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Son Hing LS, Chung-Yan GA, Hamilton LK, Zanna MP. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2008;94:771&#x2013;987.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18505312</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Stewart M, Brown JB, Donner A, McWhinney IR, Oates J, Weston WW, et al. The impact of patient-centered care on outcomes. Journal of Family Practice. 2000;49:796&#x2013;804.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">11032203</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Street RL, Jr., O&#x2019;Malley KJ, Cooper LA, Haidet P. Understanding concordance in patient-physician relationships: personal and ethnic dimensions of shared identity. Annals of Family Medicine. 2008;6:198&#x2013;205.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC2384992</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18474881</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>van Ryn M, Burgess D, Malat J, Griffin J. Physicians&#x2019; perception of patients&#x2019; social and behavioral characteristics and race disparities in treatment recommendations for men with coronary artery disease. American Journal of Public Health. 2006;96:351&#x2013;357.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC1470483</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16380577</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="Publisher" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20204166</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2019</Year><Month>11</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Mar</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Looking the Other Way: The Role of Gaze Direction in the Cross-race Memory Effect.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>478</StartPage><EndPage>481</EndPage><MedlinePgn>478-481</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>One of the most replicable findings reported in the social psychological literature is the cross-race memory effect. We argue this effect derives from higher-order interactions among social cues that determine the perceived relevance of a face to an observer. The current research tested this hypothesis by examining the combined influences of eye gaze direction and race on face memory. The physical subtlety of eye gaze belies its powerful influence on social perception, and in this case helps specify the relevance of same- versus other-race faces. We found that only in faces making direct eye contact-not those displaying averted eye gaze-was the cross-race memory effect evident. Likewise, only in same-race faces did direct relative to averted gaze enhance face memory. These findings have implications for our general understanding of the combinatorial nature of social perception and help clarify the underlying cause of the cross-race memory effect.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Adams</LastName><ForeName>Reginald B</ForeName><Initials>RB</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department The detection of gaze direction: A stare-in-the-crowd effect. Perception. 1995;24:1297&#x2013;1313.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">8643334</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Weisbuch M, Ambady N. Affective divergence: Automatic responses to others&#x2019; emotions depend on group membership. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2008;95:1063&#x2013;1079.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18954194</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zebrowitz LA. Finally, faces find favor. Social Cognition. 2006;24:657&#x2013;701.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20161549</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>1</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Jan</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Stereotype Activation, Inhibition, and Aging.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>51</StartPage><EndPage>60</EndPage><MedlinePgn>51-60</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>This research explored age-related changes in drawing stereotypic inferences during the comprehension of narrative texts. Previous research suggests that declines in inhibitory function can lead older adults to rely more on stereotypes and be more prejudiced than younger adults, even in the face of a desire to be non-prejudiced. In two experiments reported here, younger and older adults read stories that allowed for stereotypic inferences. Older adults were less likely to inhibit stereotypic inferences as measured by recognition measures and lexical decision times. A third control experiment verified that the results of the lexical decision task were not due to a priori response biases for the specific target words. Overall, older adults were more likely to make and maintain stereotypic inferences than younger adults, potentially causing them to be more prejudiced than younger adults.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Radvansky</LastName><ForeName>Gabriel A</ForeName><Initials>GA</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>University of Notre Dame.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Copeland</LastName><ForeName>David E</ForeName><Initials>DE</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>von Hippel</LastName><ForeName>William</ForeName><Initials>W</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 AG017842-01A1</GrantID><Acronym>AG</Acronym><Agency>NIA NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2010</Year><Month>2</Month><Day>18</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2010</Year><Month>2</Month><Day>18</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2010</Year><Month>2</Month><Day>18</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">20161549</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS148448</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC2805127</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2009.09.010</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Bodenhausen GV. Situation models in language comprehension and memory. Psychological Bulletin. 1998;123:162&#x2013;185.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">9522683</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20161465</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>6</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Nov</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>An Implicit Measure of Anti-Gay Attitudes: Prospective Associations with Emotion Regulation Strategies and Psychological Distress.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>1316</StartPage><EndPage>1320</EndPage><MedlinePgn>1316-1320</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Members of stigmatized groups are at increased risk for mental health problems, and recent research has suggested that emotion dysregulation may be one mechanism explaining the stigma-distress association. However, little is known regarding characteristics that predict vulnerabilities to emotion dysregulation and subsequent distress. We examined whether anti-gay attitudes would predict poorer emotion regulation and greater psychological distress in 31 lesbian, gay, and bisexual (LGB) respondents. Respondents completed implicit and explicit attitude measures at baseline, and participated in an experience sampling study examining stigma-related stressors, emotion regulation strategies, and mood over the course of ten days. Implicit and explicit attitude measures were not correlated. LGB respondents with greater implicit anti-gay attitudes engaged in significantly more rumination and suppression and reported more psychological distress. Rumination fully mediated the prospective association between implicit prejudicial attitudes and psychological distress, and suppression was a marginally significant mediator.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Hatzenbuehler</LastName><ForeName>Mark L</ForeName><Initials>ML</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Yale Development and validation of brief measures of positive and negative affect: The PANAS scales. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1988;54:1063&#x2013;1070.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">3397865</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Williams DR, Neighbors HW, Jackson JS. Racial/ethnic discrimination and health: Findings from community studies. American Journal of Public Health. 2003;93:200&#x2013;208.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC1447717</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">12554570</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Williamson I. Internalized homophobia and health issues affecting lesbians and gay men. Health Education Research. 2000;15:97&#x2013;107.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">10788206</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20161454</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>1</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Jan</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Turning the knots in your stomach into bows: Reappraising arousal improves performance on the GRE.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>208</StartPage><EndPage>212</EndPage><MedlinePgn>208-212</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>This research examined the benefits of interpreting physiological arousal as a challenge response on practice and actual Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores. Participants who were preparing to take the GRE reported to the laboratory for a practice GRE study. Participants assigned to a reappraisal condition were told arousal improves performance, whereas control participants were not given this information. We collected saliva samples at baseline and after the appraisal manipulation, which were then assayed for salivary alpha amylase (sAA), a measure of sympathetic nervous system activation. Reappraisal participants exhibited a significant increase in sAA and outperformed controls on the GRE-math section. One to three months later, participants returned to the lab and provided their score reports from their actual GRE. Again, reappraisal participants scored higher than controls on the GRE-math section. These findings illuminate the powerful influence appraisal has on physiology and performance both in and out of the laboratory.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Jamieson</LastName><ForeName>Jeremy P</ForeName><Initials>JP</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Harvard University.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Schmader</LastName><ForeName>Toni</ForeName><Initials>T</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH071749</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United International Journal of Psychophysiology. 2005;55:333&#x2013;342.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15708646</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Niedenthal PM. Embodying emotion. Science. 2007;316:1002&#x2013;1005.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">17510358</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Nosek BA, Banaji MR, Greenwald AG. Math = male, me = female, therefore math &#x2260; me. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2002;83:44&#x2013;59.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">12088131</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Schachter S, Singer J. Cognitive, social and physiological determinants of emotional state. Psychological Review. 1962;69:379&#x2013;399.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">14497895</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Schmader T, Forbes CE, Zhang S, Mendes WB. A metacognitive perspective on the cognitive deficits experienced in intellectually threatening environments. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 2009;35:584&#x2013;596.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">19228598</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20161401</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>6</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Nov</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Becoming Irreplaceable: How Comparisons to the Partner's Alternatives Differentially Affect Low and High Self-Esteem People.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>1180</StartPage><EndPage>1191</EndPage><MedlinePgn>1180-1191</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>It is proposed that people are motivated to feel hard to replace in romantic relationships because feeling irreplaceable fosters trust in a partner's continued responsiveness. By contrast, feeling replaceable motivates compensatory behavior aimed at strengthening the partner's commitment to the relationship. A correlational study of dating couples and 2 experiments examined how satiating/thwarting the goal of feeling irreplaceable differentially affects relationship perception and behavior for low and high self-esteem people. The results revealed that satiating the goal of feeling irreplaceable increases trust for people low in self-esteem. In contrast, thwarting the goal of feeling irreplaceable increases compensatory behaviors meant to prove one's indispensability for people high in self-esteem.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList Boston: Allyn and Bacon, Inc; 1978.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>White GL. Physical attractiveness and courtship progress. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1980;39:660&#x2013;668.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Williams KD, Cheung CKT, Choi W. Cyberostracism: Effects of being ignored over the Internet. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2001;79:748&#x2013;762.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">11079239</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Williams KD, Sommer KL. Social ostracism by coworkers: Does rejection lead to loafing or compensation? Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 1997;23:693&#x2013;706.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20161314</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>3</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>May</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>On Being Liked on the Web and in the "Real World": Consistency in First Impressions across Personal Webpages and Spontaneous Behavior.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>573</StartPage><EndPage>576</EndPage><MedlinePgn>573-576</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>With recent growth in the use of personal webpages and online social networking, people are changing the way that they meet and form impressions of each other. The current research examines the correspondence in impressions formed from face-to-face interaction and personal webpages. As expected, people liked by interaction partners were also liked on the basis of their Facebook((R)) pages. Across the two social mediums, social perceivers utilized analogous criteria in forming impressions: interaction partners and webpage viewers liked people who were socially expressive in face-to-face interaction and personal webpages, respectively. Finally, webpage expressivity and webpage self-disclosure were independent constructs, predictive of face-to-face counterparts: nonverbal expressivity and verbal self-disclosure. Implications for the changing landscape of social perception are discussed.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author C: American Psychological Association; 2000. pp. 199&#x2013;232.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Toma CL, Hancock JT, Ellison NB. Separating fact from fiction : An examination of deceptive self-presentation in online dating profiles. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 2008;34:1023&#x2013;1036.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18593866</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Vazire S, Gosling SD. e-perceptions: Personality impressions based on personal websites. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2004;87:123&#x2013;132.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15250797</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20161222</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>4</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Jul</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Resource Dependent Effects During Sex Categorization.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>908</StartPage><EndPage>912</EndPage><MedlinePgn>908-912</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>The limited capacity of face perception resources in the left cerebral hemisphere was examined using a sex categorization task. One study tested the hypothesis that sex categorization is impeded whenever feature extraction resources in the left hemisphere are simultaneously being utilized by another task. This hypothesis was tested by presenting prime faces for either 32 ms or 320 ms to either the left or right visual-field just before centrally presented target faces were categorized by sex. Results showed that sex categorization was slower after prime faces were presented for 32 ms in the right visual-field compared to the left visual-field. This difference was not found after the 320 ms prime length. The results are interpreted in the context of a neurocognitive model of social perception and suggest that efficient sex categorization depends, in part, on the availability of facial feature extraction resources in the left hemisphere.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Rivera</LastName><ForeName>L Person categorization and stereotyping. Social Cognition. 1990;8:161&#x2013;185.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Z&#xe1;rate MA, Stoever CJ, MacLin MK, Arms-Chavez CJ. Neurocognitive underpinnings of face perception: Further evidence of distinct person and group perception processes. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2008;94:108&#x2013;115.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18179321</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20161221</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>4</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Jul</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Counterfactual Thinking Facilitates Behavioral Intentions.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>845</StartPage><EndPage>852</EndPage><MedlinePgn>845-852</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>People often ponder what might have been, and these counterfactual inferences have been linked to behavior regulation. Counterfactuals may enhance performance by either a content-specific pathway (via shift in behavioral intentions) and/or a content-neutral pathway (via mindsets or motivation). Three experiments provided new specification of the content-specific pathway. A sequential priming paradigm revealed that counterfactual judgments facilitated RTs to complete behavioral intention judgments relative to control judgments and to a no-judgment baseline (Experiment 1). This facilitation effect was found only for intention judgments that matched the information content of the counterfactual (Experiment 2) and only for intention judgments as opposed to a different judgment that nevertheless focused on the same information content (Experiment 3). These findings clarify the content-specific pathway by which counterfactuals influence behavior.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Smallman</LastName><ForeName>Rachel</ForeName><Initials>R</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Roese</LastName><ForeName>Neal J</ForeName><Initials>NJ</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH055578</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH055578-10</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2010</Year><Month>2</Month><Day>18</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2010</Year><Month>2</Month><Day>18</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2010</Year><Month>2</Month><Day>18</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">20161221</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS100827</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC2717727</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2009.03.002</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Aarts H, Dijksterhuis A. <PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20161219</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2022</Year><Month>04</Month><Day>08</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>4</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Jul</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>A Diary Study of Implicit Self-esteem, Interpersonal Interactions and Alcohol Consumption in College Students.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>720</StartPage><EndPage>730</EndPage><MedlinePgn>720-730</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>A 30-day daily diary study examined the relations among implicit self-esteem, interpersonal interactions, and alcohol consumption in college students. Multilevel analyses revealed that students with low implicit self-esteem drank more on days when they experienced more negative interpersonal interactions. In contrast, students with high implicit self-esteem drank more on days when they experienced more positive interpersonal interactions. Spending time with people who were drinking mediated both the low implicit self-esteem by negative interpersonal events interaction and the high implicit self-esteem by positive interpersonal events interaction. These findings suggest that people with low implicit self-esteem may unintentionally drink as a way to regulate unfulfilled needs for acceptance. On the other hand, people with high implicit self-esteem may drink as a way to enhance positive interpersonal experiences.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Journal of Personality. 1991;59:609&#x2013;662.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">1960644</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wiers RW, van Woerden N, Smulders FTY, de Jong P. Implicit and explicit alcohol-related cognitions in heavy and light drinkers. Journal of Abnormal Psychology. 2002;111:648&#x2013;658.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">12428778</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wood JV, Heimpel SA, Michela JL. Savoring versus dampening: Self-esteem differences in regulating positive affect. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2003;85:566&#x2013;580.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">14498791</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20161218</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>4</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Jul</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Alone and Without Purpose: Life Loses Meaning Following Social Exclusion.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>686</StartPage><EndPage>694</EndPage><MedlinePgn>686-694</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Four studies (N = 643) supported the hypothesis that social exclusion would reduce the global perception of life as meaningful. Social exclusion was manipulated experimentally by having a confederate refuse to meet participants after seeing their videotaped introduction (Study 1) and by ostracizing participants in a computerized ball-tossing game (Study 2). Compared to control condition and acceptance conditions, social exclusion led to perceiving life as less meaningful. Exclusion was also operationalized as self-reported loneliness, which was a better predictor of low meaning than other potent variables (Study 3). Study 4 found support for Baumeister's model of meaning (1991), by demonstrating that the effect of exclusion on meaning was mediated by purpose, value, and positive self-worth.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Stillman</LastName><ForeName>Tyler F</ForeName><Initials>TF</Initials></Author><Author Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. 2004;40:560&#x2013;567.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zika S, Chamberlain K. Relation of hassles and personality to subjective well-being. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1987;53:155&#x2013;162.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zika S, Chamberlain K. On the relation between meaning in life and psychological well-being. British Journal of Psychology. 1992;83:133&#x2013;145.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">1559144</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20161043</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Sep</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Stereotype Strength and Attentional Bias: Preference for Confirming versus Disconfirming Information Depends on Processing Capacity.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>1081</StartPage><EndPage>1087</EndPage><MedlinePgn>1081-1087</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>In two experiments, we investigated the relationships among stereotype strength, processing capacity, and the allocation of attention to stereotype-consistent versus stereotype-inconsistent information describing a target person. The results of both experiments showed that, with full capacity, greater stereotype strength was associated with increased attention toward stereotype-consistent versus stereotype-inconsistent information. However, when capacity was diminished, greater stereotype strength was associated with increased attention toward inconsistent versus consistent information. Thus, strong stereotypes may act as self-confirming filters when processing capacity is plentiful, but as efficient information gathering devices that maximize the acquisition of novel (disconfirming) information when capacity is depleted. Implications for models of stereotyping and stereotype change are discussed.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Allen</LastName><ForeName>Thomas J</ForeName><Initials>TJ</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>University of California, Davis.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Sherman</LastName><ForeName>Jeffrey W</ForeName><Initials>JW</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Conrey</LastName><ForeName>Frederica R</ForeName><Initials>FR</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Stroessner</LastName><ForeName>Steven J</ForeName><Initials>SJ</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH059774-05</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2010</Year><Month>2</Month><Day>18</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2010</Year><Month>2</Month><Day>18</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2010</Year><Month>2</Month><Day>18</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">20161043</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS130977</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC2753983</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2009.06.002</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Aiken LS, West SG. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1998;75:589&#x2013;606.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">9781404</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Sherman JW, Macrae CN, Bodenhausen GV. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2005;89:607&#x2013;622.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16287422</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Srull TK. Person memory: Some tests of associative storage and retrieval models. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory and Cognition. 1981;7:440&#x2013;463.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">3157770</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Srull TK, Lichtenstein M, Rothbart M. Associative storage and retrieval processes in person memory. Journal of Experiment Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition. 1985;11:316&#x2013;345.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">3157770</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Stangor C, Duan C. Effects of multiple task demands upon memory for information about social groups. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. 1991;27:357&#x2013;378.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Stangor C, McMillan D. Memory for expectancy-congruent and expectancy-incongruent information: A review of the social and social developmental literatures. Psychological Bulletin. 1992;111:42&#x2013;61.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>von Hippel W, Jonides J, Hilton JL, Narayan S. Inhibitory effect of schematic processing on perceptual encoding. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1993;64:921&#x2013;935.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wittenbrink B, Judd CM, Park B. Evidence for racial prejudice at the implicit level and its relationship with questionnaire measures. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1997;72:262&#x2013;274.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">9107001</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Yzerbyt VY, Coull A, Rocher SJ. Fencing off the deviant: The role of cognitive resources in maintenance of stereotypes. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1999;77:449&#x2013;462.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20126295</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Feb</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Creating Hostility and Conflict: Effects of Entitlement and Self-Image Goals.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>448</StartPage><MedlinePgn>448</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>People who feel entitled to admiration and respect from others do not make good companions. This research shows one reason why. Entitled people adopt self-image goals (goals that aim to construct and defend a positive self-image), which then lead to interpersonal conflict and hostility. Studies 1A and 1B documented a unique relation between entitlement and self-image goals. Study 2 extended these results by showing, via a longitudinal design, that entitlement prospectively predicts chronic self-image goals. These chronic self-image goals then predict chronic relationship conflict and hostility, all averaged over 10 weeks. Further, Study 2 revealed that self-image goals mediate the effect of pretest entitlement on both weekly hostility and conflict. These results suggest that by pursuing self-image goals, entitled people create conflict and hostility in their relationships.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author Impulsivity and the Self-Defeating Behavior of Narcissists. Personality and Social Psychology Review. 2006;10(2):154&#x2013;165.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16768652</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zeigler-Hill V. Discrepancies Between Implicit and Explicit Self-Esteem: Implications for Narcissism and Self-Esteem Instability. Journal of Personality. 2006;74(1):119&#x2013;143.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">16451228</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zeigler-Hill V, Clark CB, Pickard JD. Narcissistic subtypes and contingent self-esteem: Do all narcissists base their self-esteem on the same domains? Journal of Personality. 2008;76(4):753&#x2013;774.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18482357</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20126293</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2024</Year><Month>01</Month><Day>09</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>2</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Feb</Month><Day>01</Day></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>The Intergenerational Transmission of Implicit and Explicit Attitudes Toward Smoking.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>313</StartPage><MedlinePgn>313</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>This study examined the intergenerational transmission of implicit and explicit attitudes toward smoking, as well as the role of these attitudes in adolescents' smoking initiation. There was evidence of intergenerational transmission of implicit attitudes. Mothers who had more positive implicit attitudes had children with more positive implicit attitudes. In turn, these positive implicit attitudes of adolescents predicted their smoking initiation 18-months later. Moreover, these effects were obtained above and beyond the effects of explicit attitudes. These findings provide the first evidence that the intergenerational transmission of implicit cognition may play a role in the intergenerational transmission of an addictive behavior.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Sherman</LastName><ForeName>Steven J</ForeName><Initials>SJ</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Indiana Substance Use and Misuse. 2004;39:1625&#x2013;1684.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15587947</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wiers RW, Gunning WB, Sergeant JA. Do young children of alcoholics hold more positive or negative alcohol-related expectancies than controls? Alcoholism: Clinical and Experimental Research. 1998;22:1855&#x2013;1863.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">9835308</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wiers RW, Houben K, Smulders FTY, Conrod PJ, Jones BT. To drink or not to drink: The role of automatic and controlled processes in the etiology of alcohol-related problems. In: Wiers RW, Stacy AW, editors. Handbook of implicit cognition and addiction. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage; 2006b. pp. 339&#x2013;361.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zentner M, Renaud O. Origins of adolescents&#x2019; ideal self: An intergenerational perspective. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2007;92:557&#x2013;574.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">17352609</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20047023</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>3</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Too Tired to Tell the Truth: Self-Control Resource Depletion and Dishonesty.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>594</StartPage><EndPage>597</EndPage><MedlinePgn>594-597</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>The opportunity to profit from dishonesty evokes a motivational conflict between the temptation to cheat for selfish gain and the desire to act in a socially appropriate manner. Honesty may depend on self-control given that self-control is the capacity that enables people to override antisocial selfish responses in favor of socially desirable responses. Two experiments tested the hypothesis that dishonesty would increase when people's self-control resources were depleted by an initial act of self-control. Depleted participants misrepresented their performance for monetary gain to a greater extent than did non-depleted participants (Experiment 1). Perhaps more troubling, depleted participants were more likely than non-depleted participants to expose themselves to the temptation to cheat, thereby aggravating the effects of depletion on cheating (Experiment 2). Results indicate that dishonesty increases when people's capacity to exert self-control is impaired, and that people may be particularly vulnerable to this effect because they do not predict it.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Mead</LastName><ForeName>Nicole L</ForeName><Initials>NL</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Florida State Attention control, memory updating, and emotion regulation temporarily reduce the capacity for executive control. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General. 2007;136:241&#x2013;255.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">17500649</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Vohs KD, Heatherton TF. Self-regulatory failure: A resource-depletion approach. Psychological Science. 2000;11:249&#x2013;254.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">11273412</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Watson D, Clark LA, Tellegen A. Development and validation of brief measures of positive and negative affect: The PANAS scales. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1988;54:1063&#x2013;1070.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">3397865</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">20047001</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>1</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Jan</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Self-Esteem Depends on the Beholder: Effects of a Subtle Social Value Cue.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>143</StartPage><EndPage>148</EndPage><MedlinePgn>143-148</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>The idea that self-esteem functions as a gauge or "sociometer" of social value (Leary &amp; Baumeister, 2000) is supported by research on direct social feedback. To examine if the sociometer model is relevant to more subtle social value cues, the implicit self-esteem of women was assessed a week after an interaction with an experimenter. Consistent with the sociometer model, Week 2 self-esteem depended on a subtle social value cue encountered during Week 1. When the Week 1 experimenter wore a t-shirt celebrating larger bodies (i.e., "everyBODY is beautiful"), heavier women had higher self-esteem than lighter women in Week 2. As hypothesized, this effect was relationship-specific, occurring only when the same experimenter administered Week 1 and 2 sessions.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author The silent treatment: Perceptions of its behaviors and associated feelings. Group Processes and Intergroup Relations. 1998;1:117&#x2013;141.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zadro L, Williams KD, Richardson R. Riding the &#x2018;O&#x2019; train: Comparing the effects of ostracism and verbal dispute on targets and sources. Group Processes and Intergroup Relations. 2004;8:125&#x2013;143.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21836727</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>46</Volume><Issue>1</Issue><PubDate><Year>2010</Year><Month>Jan</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Reconstruction of things past: Why do some memories feel so close and others so far away?</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>217</StartPage><EndPage>220</EndPage><MedlinePgn>217-220</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>The vast majority of work in construal level theory focuses prospectively on the future. Through a series of studies controlling for knowledge about an event, we look retrospectively at the past and demonstrate that construal mindsets can materially influence how a past event is reconstructed in memory. Specifically, an event recalled in a more concrete mindset feels subjectively closer than when recalled in an abstract mindset (Studies 1-3). We present evidence suggesting this is because a concrete mindset actually makes people feel as though they know more, even if they were initially exposed to the same set of information-perceived information accessibility mediates the effect of construal level on temporal distance (Study 2). The effect of construal level on memory reconstruction extends to judgments of blame, where judgments of greater temporal distance drive a greater propensity to blame parties for negative events and temporal distance mediates these judgments (Study 3). Together, these studies are the first to demonstrate that the mindset employed when recalling an event shapes its remembrance.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Kyung</LastName><ForeName>Ellie J</ForeName><Initials>EJ</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>New York University, USA.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Menon</LastName><ForeName>Geeta</ForeName><Initials>G</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Trope</LastName><ForeName>Yaacov</ForeName><Initials>Y</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH059030</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH059030-09</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2011</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>28</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2010</Year><Month>1</Month><Day>1</Day><Hour>0</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2010</Year><Month>1</Month><Day>1</Day><Hour>0</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">21836727</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS314601</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3152818</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2009.09.003</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Brainerd CJ, Reyna VF. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1999;76:877&#x2013;892.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">10402678</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Trope Y, Liberman N. Temporal construal. Psychological Review. 2003;110:403&#x2013;421.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">12885109</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wilson AE, Ross M. The identity function of autobiographical memory: Time is on our side. Memory. 2003;11:137&#x2013;149.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">12820827</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">19884971</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>227</Volume><Issue>21</Issue><PubDate><Year>2008</Year><Month>Nov</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Influencing Attitudes Toward Near and Distant Objects.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>9044</StartPage><EndPage>9062</EndPage><MedlinePgn>9044-9062</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>It is argued that the temporal distance of attitude objects systematically changes how the object is mentally represented, and thus influences the strength of particular persuasive appeals. Three experiments tested the hypothesis that people preferentially attend to arguments that highlight primary, abstract (high-level) vs. incidental, concrete (low-level) features when attitude objects are temporally distant vs. near. Results suggested that when attitude objects are temporally distant vs. near, arguments emphasizing primary vs. secondary features (Study 1), desirability vs. feasibility features (Study 2), and general classes vs. specific cases are more persuasive (Study 3). The relation of construal theory to dual process theories of persuasion and persuasion phenomena, such as personal relevance effects and functional matching effects, are discussed.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Fujita</LastName><ForeName>Kentaro</ForeName><Initials>K</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>The Ohio Journal of Consumer Psychology. 2007;17:83&#x2013;95.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC3150814</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">21822366</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Updegraff JA, Sherman DK, Luyster FS, Mann TL. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. 2007;43:249&#x2013;257.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC2573043</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">18958299</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Vallacher RR, Wegner DM. Levels of personal agency: Individual variation in action identification. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1989;57:660&#x2013;671.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wakslak CJ, Trope Y, Liberman N, Alony R. Seeing the forest when entry is unlikely: probability and the mental representation of events. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General. 2006;155:641&#x2013;653.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">17087578</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Wheeler SC, Petty RE, Bizer GY. Self-schema matching and attitude change: Situational and dispositional determinants of message elaboration. Journal of Consumer Research. 2005;31:787&#x2013;797.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">19727428</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>44</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2008</Year><Month>Sep</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Attending to Threat: Race-based Patterns of Selective Attention.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>1322</StartPage><EndPage>1327</EndPage><MedlinePgn>1322-1327</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>The present research investigated the extent to which the stereotype that young Black men are threatening and dangerous has become so robust and ingrained in the collective American unconscious that Black men now capture attention, much like evolved threats such as spiders and snakes. Specifically, using a dot-probe detection paradigm, White participants revealed biased attention toward Black faces relative to White faces (Study 1). Because the faces were presented only briefly (30-ms), the bias is thought to reflect the early engagement of attention. The attentional bias was eliminated, however, when the faces displayed averted eye-gaze (Study 2). That is, when the threat communicated by the Black faces was attenuated by a relevant, competing socio-emotional cue- in this case, averted eye-gaze-they no longer captured perceivers' attention. Broader implications for social cognition, as well as public policies that reify these prevailing perceptions of young Black men are discussed.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Trawalter</LastName><ForeName>Sophie</ForeName><Initials>S</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Department of Psychology &amp; Institute for Policy Research, Northwestern University.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Todd</LastName><ForeName>Andrew R</ForeName><Initials>AR</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Baird</LastName><ForeName>Abigail A</ForeName><Initials>AA</Initials></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Richeson</LastName><ForeName>Jennifer A</ForeName><Initials>JA</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>F32 HD055772</GrantID><Acronym>HD</Acronym><Agency>NICHD NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>F32 HD055772-01</GrantID><Acronym>HD</Acronym><Agency>NICHD NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2009</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>4</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2009</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>4</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2009</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>4</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">19727428</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS67957</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC2633407</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2008.03.006</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Ackerman JM, Shapiro JR, Neuberg SL, Kenrick DT, Becker DV, Griskevicius V, Maner JK, Schaller M. Controlling racial prejudice: Social-cognitive goals affect amygdala and stereotype activation. Psychological Science. 2005;16:56&#x2013;63.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15660852</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">19727425</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>44</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2008</Year><Month>Sep</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>"You're Just Saying That." Contingencies of Self-Worth, Suspicion, and Authenticity in the Interpersonal Affirmation Process.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>1376</StartPage><EndPage>1382</EndPage><MedlinePgn>1376-1382</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>A model of the role and costs of contingent self-worth in the partner-affirmation process was tested. Actors whose self-worth was contingent on appearance or intelligence claimed to have expressed their particular heightened sensitivity to their romantic partners. Suggesting a cost to these reactions, actors' beliefs about having expressed heightened sensitivity, in turn, predicted their doubts about the authenticity of partners' positive feedback in the domain of contingency, independently of whether partners claimed to deliver inauthentic feedback. Suggesting a cost for partners, partners of contingent actors appeared to detect actors' expressions of sensitivity in the domain of contingency and respond by delivering inauthentic feedback to actors in the domain, which in turn predicted partners' increased relationship anxiety and decreased satisfaction. Results suggest that contingent self-worth may undermine the functioning of the partner-affirmation process through actors discrediting partners' positive feedback and partners behaving in an inauthentic and controlled manner.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Lemay</LastName><ForeName>Edward P</ForeName><Initials>EP</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Yale University.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Clark</LastName><ForeName>Margaret S</ForeName><Initials>MS</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>F31 MH072031-03</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant></GrantList><PublicationTypeList><PublicationType UI="D016428">Journal Article</PublicationType></PublicationTypeList></Article><MedlineJournalInfo><Country>United States</Country><MedlineTA>J Exp Soc Psychol</MedlineTA><NlmUniqueID>0045332</NlmUniqueID><ISSNLinking>0022-1031</ISSNLinking></MedlineJournalInfo></MedlineCitation><PubmedData><History><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="entrez"><Year>2009</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>4</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="pubmed"><Year>2009</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>4</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>0</Minute></PubMedPubDate><PubMedPubDate PubStatus="medline"><Year>2009</Year><Month>9</Month><Day>4</Day><Hour>6</Hour><Minute>1</Minute></PubMedPubDate></History><PublicationStatus>ppublish</PublicationStatus><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">19727425</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="mid">NIHMS68003</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="pmc">PMC2630212</ArticleId><ArticleId IdType="doi">10.1016/j.jesp.2008.05.001</ArticleId></ArticleIdList><ReferenceList><Reference><Citation>Baron RM, Kenny DA. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 2004;30:905&#x2013;914.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15200696</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Reis HT, Clark MS, Holmes JG. Oxford, England: John Wiley &amp; Sons; 1988. pp. 367&#x2013;389.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Rosenberg M. Society and the adolescent self-image. Princeton, NJ: Princeton Univ. Press; 1965.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Sagarin BJ, Rhoads KvL, Cialdini RB. Deceiver's distrust: Denigration as a consequence of undiscovered deception. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 1998;24:1167&#x2013;1176.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Shaver PR, Schachner DA, Mikulincer M. Attachment style, excessive reassurance seeking, relationship processes, and depression. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. 2005;31:343&#x2013;359.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">15657450</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Stroebe W, Eagly AH, Stroebe MS. Friendly or just polite? The effect of self-esteem on attributions. European Journal of Social Psychology. 1977;7:265&#x2013;274.</Citation></Reference><Reference><Citation>Swann WB. Identity negotiation: Where two roads meet. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1987;53:1038&#x2013;1051.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">3320335</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Vonk R. The slime effect: Suspicion and dislike of likeable behavior toward superiors. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1998;74:849&#x2013;864.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">19727421</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2023</Year><Month>11</Month><Day>05</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>44</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2008</Year><Month>Sep</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>How Preferences For Eager Versus Vigilant Judgment Strategies Affect Self-Serving Conclusions.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>1219</StartPage><EndPage>1228</EndPage><MedlinePgn>1219-1228</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>People are often motivated to reach self-serving conclusions during judgment. This article examines how such self-serving judgment outcomes are influenced by preferences for different judgment strategies. Two studies tested how preferences for eager (promotion-oriented) versus vigilant (prevention-oriented) judgment strategies affected self-serving explanations for success or failure. Regardless of their performance, those preferring vigilant strategies selectively endorsed a few explanations above others, whereas those preferring eager strategies more evenly endorsed multiple explanations. Furthermore, although the explanations selected by those preferring vigilant strategies were indeed self-serving (emphasizing personal responsibility for success and external circumstances for failure), the more balanced endorsement of multiple explanations by those preferring eager strategies was associated with attenuated self-serving tendencies. Finally, those preferring eager strategies were also less self-serving in their generalization from explanations of current performance to predictions of future performance. The larger implications of these findings for the role of strategic preferences in judgment are discussed.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Molden</LastName><ForeName>Daniel C</ForeName><Initials>DC</Initials><AffiliationInfo><Affiliation>Northwestern University.</Affiliation></AffiliationInfo></Author><Author ValidYN="Y"><LastName>Higgins</LastName><ForeName>E Tory</ForeName><Initials>ET</Initials></Author></AuthorList><Language>eng</Language><GrantList CompleteYN="Y"><Grant><GrantID>F31 HHS</Agency><Country>United States</Country></Grant><Grant><GrantID>R01 MH039429-22</GrantID><Acronym>MH</Acronym><Agency>NIMH NIH HHS</Agency><Country>United Reconciling competing motives in self-evaluation: The role of self-control in feedback seeking. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1994;66:646&#x2013;657.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">8189345</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Weiner B. An attributional theory of achievement motivation and emotion. Psychological Review. 1985;92:548&#x2013;573.</Citation><ArticleIdList><ArticleId IdType="pubmed">3903815</ArticleId></ArticleIdList></Reference><Reference><Citation>Zuckerman M. Attribution of success and failure revisited, or: The motivational bias is alive and well in attribution theory. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 1979;47:245&#x2013;287.</Citation></Reference></ReferenceList></PubmedData></PubmedArticle><PubmedArticle><MedlineCitation Status="PubMed-not-MEDLINE" Owner="NLM"><PMID Version="1">21822331</PMID><DateRevised><Year>2021</Year><Month>10</Month><Day>20</Day></DateRevised><Article PubModel="Print"><Journal><ISSN IssnType="Print">0022-1031</ISSN><JournalIssue CitedMedium="Print"><Volume>45</Volume><Issue>5</Issue><PubDate><Year>2009</Year><Month>Sep</Month></PubDate></JournalIssue><Title>Journal of experimental social psychology</Title><ISOAbbreviation>J Exp Soc Psychol</ISOAbbreviation></Journal><ArticleTitle>Spontaneous trait inference and construal level theory: Psychological distance increases nonconscious trait thinking.</ArticleTitle><Pagination><StartPage>1088</StartPage><EndPage>1097</EndPage><MedlinePgn>1088-1097</MedlinePgn></Pagination><Abstract><AbstractText>Can psychological distance affect how much perceivers form spontaneous trait inferences (STI) from others' behaviors? On the basis of construal level theory (CLT) which posits that distant (vs. near) entities are represented more in terms of their abstract, global, and decontextualized features, we predicted that perceived distance would increase the tendency for perceivers to draw spontaneous trait inferences from behavioral information about actors. In two experiments, participants learned about people who were perceived as being distant or proximal to the self, and STI formation was subsequently assessed. We found that perceivers were more likely to form STIs about distant vs. near actors from the same behavioral information. These findings generalized across two distance dimensions: space and time. In addition, we found that priming individuals to adopt a high-level (vs. low-level) construal mindset also resulted in increased STI (Experiment 3). In sum, psychological distance facilitates STI formation, and this occurs via high-level construal of actors and their behaviors.</AbstractText></Abstract><AuthorList CompleteYN="Y"><Author
